issue.title: cmake: tidy up more in Find modules

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
- add `NAMES` where missing.
- document input variables (including deprecated ones.)
- comment cleanups.
- FindWolfSSL: drop stray `QUIET` from `pkg_check_modules()`.
  (`QUIET` may be re-added for all modules in the future.)

---

- [x] move `cmakelint` fixes to separate PR. â†’ #14583
- [ ] move `FindNettle` behaviour updates to separate PR.

w/o whitespace: https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/14579/files?w=1

body:
Pushed some fixes to existing PR #14579

1. I was just wondering about the naming of Find* modules. It's a bit all over the place. Also CMake built-in ones are.
`cmakelint` suggests full uppercase component names after `Find`. I'm fine with this, but as this `cmakelint` Issue [notes](https://github.com/cmake-lint/cmake-lint/issues/24), CMake itself [doesn't suggest](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/manual/cmake-developer.7.html#standard-variable-names) such convention and I also cannot see it confirmed "in the wild".

I'd probably just do capital and then use whatever the component is named, and leave most existing uppercased ones as-is, changing only these:
```
FindLibPSL  -> FindLibpsl
FindLibSSH2 -> FindLibssh2
FindQUICHE  -> FindQuiche
Findrustls  -> FindRustls
```

Either way it will need a separate PR just for that. But first what scheme should we follow here, if any?

2. As for the "weird indentation" issues: It caught two that I was aware of (fixed now!), but the rest I'm conflicted with. `cmakelint` wants to indent multiline `if(` expression to the 2-char levels and calls it weird when aligned with the preceding `if(`. This recommendation IMO reduce readability for these expressions.

Found these two solutions:
- avoid multiline expressions. By unfolding or splitting to nested `if()`s. This is also weird, and may not be applicable to all expressions without reducing readability.
- suppress the warning with `--filter=-whitespace/indent`. This looks harsh, but this option doesn't seem to catch real indentation issues anyway. (tried by unindenting, overindenting instructions under a `function` and `if`, neither triggering warnings.

I noticed that multiline indentation issue as well. That might be worth
bringing upstream as a bug, since indenting while ignoring the parenthesis
is definitely a step down in readability.

Even if half the checks are disabled, it still leaves half the checks in
effect, so it's still a gain in consistency.
Absolutely, I think it's a nice candidate for a new CI job. Would you want to add one?

However I try to extract some "packagename" convention or recommendation from the internet, there is hardly any. CMake authors cannot or are unwilling to recommend anything tangible.

Even the often seen capital-case rule is wrong; simply there is no package named `Libssh2` or `Libidn2`, so naming them just for the sake of having a filename `FindCapital.cmake` seems ...odd. All the while all internal variable references are `LIBSSH2_*` or `LIBIDN2_*` in uppercase.

Almost nobody uses a `Findlowercase.cmake` styled name, even though that would make most sense to match how these packages are named in every existing package manager and how most projects refer to themselves.

Perhaps one clue could be what project name each dependency uses in their CMake build files (if they have them). For `libssh2` this would be `libssh2` in lowercase, same for `brotli`, `libssh`, `nghttp2`, `nghttp3`, `ngtcp2`, `wolfssl`, `zlib`, `zstd`. Exceptions are: `c-ares` (lowercase with dash), `Mbed TLS`, `LibreSSL` (doesn't need a Find module).

Here's how the variants would look like:
```
    lower               Mixed               UPPER
Findbearssl.cmake   FindBearSSL.cmake   FindBEARSSL.cmake
Findbrotli.cmake    FindBrotli.cmake    FindBROTLI.cmake
Findcares.cmake     FindCARES.cmake     FindCARES.cmake
Findgss.cmake       FindGSS.cmake       FindGSS.cmake
Findlibgsasl.cmake  FindLibgsasl.cmake  FindLIBGSASL.cmake
Findlibidn2.cmake   FindLibidn2.cmake   FindLIBIDN2.cmake
Findlibpsl.cmake    FindLibpsl.cmake    FindLIBPSL.cmake
Findlibssh.cmake    FindLibssh.cmake    FindLIBSSH.cmake
Findlibssh2.cmake   FindLibssh2.cmake   FindLIBSSH2.cmake
Findlibuv.cmake     FindLibuv.cmake     FindLIBUV.cmake
Findmsh3.cmake      FindMSH3.cmake      FindMSH3.cmake
Findmbedtls.cmake   FindMbedTLS.cmake   FindMBEDTLS.cmake
Findnettle.cmake    FindNettle.cmake    FindNETTLE.cmake
Findnghttp2.cmake   FindNGHTTP2.cmake   FindNGHTTP2.cmake
Findnghttp3.cmake   FindNGHTTP3.cmake   FindNGHTTP3.cmake
Findngtcp2.cmake    FindNGTCP2.cmake    FindNGTCP2.cmake
Findquiche.cmake    FindQuiche.cmake    FindQUICHE.cmake
Findrustls.cmake    FindRustls.cmake    FindRUSTLS.cmake
Findwolfssh.cmake   FindWolfSSH.cmake   FindWOLFSSH.cmake
Findwolfssl.cmake   FindWolfSSL.cmake   FindWOLFSSL.cmake
Findzstd.cmake      FindZstd.cmake      FindZSTD.cmake
```

issue.title: cmake: fix `cmakelint` warnings

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
- keep lines below 132 characters.
- fix two "weird indentations" warnings.

Reported-by: Dan Fandrich
Bug: #14580

body:
more tests later...

The filename of the Find modules must match the name passed to `find_package()`. This isn't obvious at first because it's not documented, and it depends on the filesystem's case-sensitivity. E.g. on macOS (and Windows) they are matched case-insensitvely.

That name also must match the one passed to `find_package_handle_standard_args()` in the Find module itself, to avoid a CMake warning.

CMake also picks up a 'cmake-config' file with this name. According to [docs](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/command/find_package.html#search-modes), it looks for: `<lowercasePackageName>-config.cmake`, `<PackageName>Config.cmake`, and `<lowercasePackageName>-config-version.cmake`.

Meaning it may be useful to match the casing of package provided 'cmake-config', if there is one.

I'm shifting towards the ambiguous and arbitrary, but probably more "CMake-like" _mixed case_ naming, with a preference to match the package convention, and falling back to Capitalized otherwise.
Sure, I can add a job for this.

issue.title: cmake: rename Find modules

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
- `FindCARES` -> `FindCares`
- `FindLibPSL` -> `FindLibpsl`
- `FindLibSSH2` -> `FindLibssh2`
- `FindQUICHE` -> `FindQuiche`
- `Findrustls` -> `FindRustls`

Our convention for naming Find modules (the part after the `Find`
prefix, also called as 'package name') is:

Start with uppercase. Follow with lowercase, unless there is a clear
preference for a stylized name. E.g. the project itself uses it that way
with a matching `<Name>Config.cmake` file, or we use it that way
elsewhere, or the name is an acronym.

Ref: #14580

body:
@dfandrich Sounds good!

Opened a PR with the renames mentioned above:
https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/14601

I think this describes the convention that I'm aiming at with package names:
Always start with uppercase and follow with lowercase, unless there is a clear
preference for a stylized name. (E.g. the project itself uses it that way with
a matching `<Name>Config.cmake` file, we use it that way elsewhere, or
the name is an acronym.
